pullRequest.title: Dynamic logging for connect
pullRequest.bodyText:
Signed-off-by: Stanislav Knot sknot@redhat.com
Type of change

Enhancement / new feature

Description
Fixes #2807
This PR uses KIP-495
The algorithm:
inline:

current loggers are fetched
all loggers are set to OFF in the map
desired loggers are set to their levels in the map
the loggers map is sorted (because of generality [org.company vs org.company.name])
the loggers are set by sending API REST requests

external:
for loggers it is the same as for the inline
for appenders: appenders are added to the annotation (the connect pod is rolled, as changing appenders dynamically is not possible)
Checklist

nodes.bodyText: Same as above ... do we really need this?

How does this differ from ANNO_STRIMZI_LOGGING_APPENDERS_HASH from #3469 ? Is it really different annotation - i.e. not hash? If yes, why are we using hash there and not here? I guess we need to keep the old values and be able to recover them?

Would it be better to filter out here what you can set dynamically and keep the rest for the rolling update? I guess the same applies to #3469?

commit.message:
remove unchecked suppressions

Signed-off-by: Stanislav Knot <sknot@redhat.com>

nodes.bodyText: Can we factor ObjectMapper into a constant, since it's thread safe it should be OK to reuse the same instance across all methods in this class.
I think you should refactor the .split(",")[0].replaceAll("\\s", "")  into a method and provide a comment explaining it.

That's horribly inefficient. Replace all needs to compile a Pattern, and you allocate a new String just to compute its length. for (int i = 0; i < tested.length(); i++) { if (tested.charAt(i) == '.') count++ }.
Why not k1.compareTo(k2)? Because a prefix is < every string of which it is a prefix.
Does it really need to be in AbstractOperator though? It seems like a utility method to me.
512 bit hash => 64 bytes => 128 chars in the string. I don't think we need to be so resilient to a collision that we need to spend that much effort. 64 bits would be more than enough IMHO.

This should be just called stringHash(). Why the fetish with prefixing every method which returns something with get?
Also some Java doc would not go amiss.
